Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Hawaiian PLUME Deployment in a Global Context
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hawaii's location far from any plate boundary provides an excellent opportunity to test the plume hypothesis: whether hot upwellings from the deep mantle generate hotspot volcanism at the Earth?s surface. Initial seismic imaging for the "Plume-Lithosphere Undersea Melt Experiment" (PLUME), consisting of a temporary deployment of land and ocean bottom seismometers, has revealed the first high-resolution 3-D images that support the presence of a deep-anchored mantle plume. Yet, the PLUME seismic recordings have yet to be exploited to their fullest. The body and surface wave datasets that have so far been analyzed independently, as is usually the case, must be modeled jointly. This will help distinguish between temperature anomalies, which are usually assumed to cause seismic anomalies, and other causes such as changes in rock composition or mechanical strength. Another part of this research is the understanding of how seismic waves attenuate beneath Hawaii, and this project will extract new attenuation data from the seismic records. We will also place the PLUME dataset in a global context by embedding it in a global model. Global tomography can address fundamental questions that an isolated interpretation of the PLUME dataset cannot provide: Does the Hawaiian plume have its own isolated origin near the core-mantle boundary or does it originate from the large low shear-velocity province in the Central Pacific? Is the currently imaged tilt of the deep mantle anomaly in the regional body wave images a robust feature that persists in a global model? Does a connection with the East Pacific Rise exist in the asthenosphere that would explain some of the complex chemistry found in Hawaii's basalts?

Scientists have long debated whether hotspots such as Hawaii, Yellowstone, or Iceland are the product of hot, buoyant upwelling "mantle plumes" from the lower mantle, perhaps originating as deep as the core mantle boundary, or are rather the result of processes in the shallow mantle. Seismic studies can help resolve such questions, because seismic waves can be used to reveal Earth?s internal structure through tomographic images and detect regions of high temperatures, mantle rock anomalies and melt. This project will perform enhanced analyses of data from a unique deployment of land and ocean bottom seismometers (OBSs) around the Hawaiian Islands and across the anomalous region of uplifted seafloor known as the Hawaiian Swell. Prior analyses of this deployment for the "Plume-Lithosphere Undersea Melt Experiment" (PLUME), support the presence of a mantle plume, but more detailed studies are needed to help answer fundamental questions, including: Does the Hawaiian plume originate from its own isolated origin near the core-mantle boundary or does it originate from the large low shear-velocity province in the Central Pacific? Is the plume in fact a continuous chimney-like feature or does it break up into several blobs? Is the currently imaged tilt of the seismic anomaly a robust feature that persists in a global tomography model? Does a connection with the nearest major mid-ocean ridge, the East Pacific Rise, exist in Earth's shallower layer known as the asthenosphere, which would explain some of the complex chemistry that geochemists have found in Hawaii's lavas?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Plume-Lithosphere-Undersea-Mantle Experiment (PLUME) investigated the seismic structure of the mantle beneath Hawaii in search of the ultimate source and supply route of Hawaii's volcanic materials. PLUME was the first large-scale experiment that used newly developed broadband ocean bottom seismometer (OBS) packages to record earthquakes remotely for upward of a year. The original PLUME deployments took place between 2005 and 2007, and several publications described important new discoveries: seismic body waves revealed that Hawaii's volcanoes are indeed fed by a source that is located deep in the lower mantle, i.e. through a deep-rooted mantle plume, well to the southeast of Hawaii. In the lithosphere and asthenosphere down to 200 km depth, PLUME imaged a rather lopsided upper mantle with the center of anomalously hot mantle located to the west of the island of Hawaii rather than directly beneath the island as expected.

This follow-up grant supported work to combine the initially collected surface wave dataset with other seismic datasets to enhance imaging of the upper mantle. In particular, surface waves cannot provide focused images of discontinuities such as the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary. On the other hand, body waves of a certain type (compressional or shear) convert to other phases when crossing such boundaries. These conversions can be analyzed through receiver functions, the transfer function between the vertical and radial seismogram components. A combined surface wave and receiver function analysis allowed us to outline the anomalously hot region west of Hawaii in better detail. In particular, we defined the onset of melting of the ascending mantle plume material at up to 155 km below the Earth's surface. On its ascent, the plume material then has to migrate around a relatively 'cold' restive root located beneath the island of Hawaii. Our findings document complex upwelling of mantle material rather than the simple vertical upwelling found in many tank experiments.

We also investigated azimuthal changes in surface wave velocities, i.e. azimuthal anisotropy. Azimuthal changes are expected when anisotropic minerals align with the flowing mantle. In Hawaii, we would expect a change in anisotropy with depth. In the lithosphere, past mantle flow is "frozen" in after minerals oriented with past flow directions, before the rearrangement of plate motion in the Pacific. Deeper down in the asthenosphere, we expect anisotropy to be aligned with the current plate motion direction. Our surface-wave dataset supports this idea, while shear-wave splitting data (anisotropy found in shear wave travel times) seem to be insensive to the latter.

A third study investigated the feasibility of detecting very small signals in OBS data that result from transmisions and reflections off the D" layer just above the core-mantle boundary. Indeed, the PLUME waveforms provided invaluable new data to provide D" property data in previously unmapped regions beneath the Pacific ocean.

When long-period ocean waves pass an OBS, the associated pressure fluctuations (recorded by a pressure sensor) cause deformations of the seafloor (recorded by a seismometer). In a forth project, we started to investigate shallow crustal structure using PLUME compliance data, the transfer function between seafloor deformation and pressure. Compliance is an excellent dataset to study crustal structure. This in turn is important because previously unknown variations in crustal structure can erroneously map into anomalies in the mantle. Results from the compliance study will help us refine images of the upper mantle beneath.

Broader impacts: this research supported two graduate students and several female undergraduate students. PLUME research was published in high-impact journals such as Science and Nature Geoscience, featured in a TV production on the Hawaiian mantle plume, in Cricket Magazine for Kids, and several public outreach venues.
